required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Performance of QDOT Micro™ Catheter With nGEN Generator for Patients With AFIB.
clinical_study.official_title: Acute Performance Evaluation of the QDOT Micro™ Catheter Used With nGEN Generator in Treatment of Patients With Atrial Fibrillation.

brief_summary.textblock: This workflow study will further evaluate the acute performance and safety of the QDOT MICRO™ catheter in a clinical setting used in combination with nGEN Generator. Subjects will be followed for 7 days post procedure.

primary_outcome.description: Confirmation of entrance block in all targeted PVs after adenosine and/or isoproterenol challenge using the nGEN / QDOT Micro Ablation System

intervention.description: QDOT Micro Catheter with nGEN Generator

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Subjects diagnosed with symptomatic paroxysmal or early persistent AF undergoing a catheter ablation procedure through pulmonary vein isolation.
2. Age 18 or older.
3. Signed the Patient Informed Consent Form (ICF).
Exclusion Criteria:
1. If the patient has had a ventriculotomy or atriotomy within the preceding twelve weeks.
2. Presence of a myxoma or an intracardiac thrombus.
3. Presence of prosthetic valves.
4. Presence of active systemic infection
5. Patient with an interatrial baffle or patch
6. Women who are pregnant (as evidenced by pregnancy test if pre-menopausal), lactating, or who are of child bearing age and plan on becoming pregnant during the course of the clinical investigation.

facility.name: Institut de Cardiologie de Montréal (Montreal Heart Institute)

patient_data.ipd_description: Johnson & Johnson Medical Device Companies have an agreement with the Yale Open Data Access (YODA) Project to serve as the independent review panel for evaluation of requests for clinical study reports and participant level data from investigators and physicians for scientific research that will advance medical knowledge and public health. Requests for access to the study data can be submitted through the YODA Project site at http://yoda.yale.edu.
